essay:
Derrick Henry rushed for 28.7 points in Week 1. He is thirty-one years old. He has more than 2,000 career carries. He was supposed to be the cautionary tale, the guy we pointed to when we warned Sleeping Giants that Father Time was undefeated. Instead, he dragged zbcowan's squad to 151.48 points and the number-one power ranking in the league. The preseason number-eleven team. Sitting at the top. If this were a movie, it would be the opening scene of Rocky Balboa where everyone assumes he's washed and then he starts punching meat again.

Meanwhile, in a quieter corner of the scoreboard, Josh Allen dropped 38.76 points for Rasheeing the Scene — the kind of performance that makes you whisper to yourself, 'Maybe this is the year he finally gets a real receiver corps.' He won't. But for one Sunday, it didn't matter. Allen outscored entire teams by himself, and ToreroGaucho rode that lightning to a comfortable win over Noble FFT, whose preseason number-two ranking suddenly looks like the kind of projection that ages like milk left on a Houston porch in August.

The group chat was uncharacteristically quiet for about forty-five minutes after the Boonist Monks dropped 144.36 on Ghastly Grayskull Gang. Not quiet in the respectful way — quiet in the 'nobody wants to be the first to say it' way. Lamar Jackson went for 29.36, James Cook added 18.7, and GrayskullXX's roster responded with a collective shrug and 109.42 points. The preseason number-four team posted the week's lowest score. Somewhere, a mountain of draft picks weeps silently.

But here's the storyline nobody's talking about yet: the preseason top three — General Ken-obi, Noble FFT, and MHJTIME — went a combined 1-2 in Week 1. Only bLaker24 escaped with a win, and even that felt muted: 135.88 points against a Father Time squad that could only muster 120.68. CeeDee Lamb contributed 14.5 and Saquon added 16.4, which is fine, but 'fine' doesn't win you championships. It wins you Tuesday morning nods in the group chat.

MHJTIME scored 142.62 points and still lost. Read that again. In most weeks, against most teams, that's a win. But rango_ drew Sleeping Giants in Week 1, and Derrick Henry and Jalen Hurts combined for 52.98 points. That's the kind of beat that would make you close your fantasy app and open a meditation app instead. The worst part? We wrote in the preseason that MHJTIME's running backs were 'patchwork.' Turns out, scoring 142 doesn't matter when your opponent's running backs remember what decade they peaked in and decide to do it again.

Kittler on the Roof handled business against Chudders, 143.72 to 133.82. The defending champion didn't need fireworks — Garrett Wilson and Puka Nacua combined for 37.1 points at receiver, and the defense carried the rest. Consistency. That's the Kittler brand. We said in the preseason that your floor was 'nice but your ceiling might be drywall.' Week 1 was drywall. Winning drywall, but drywall.

One week in and the entire preseason hierarchy is scrambled. The bottom two preseason teams sit in the top four. The consensus top two both lost. This is dynasty football. This is The Jailyard. Buckle your seatbelt — we've got thirteen more weeks of this before anyone clinches anything.

rankings.blurb: Preseason rank: eleven. Week 1 rank: one. You weren't supposed to be here yet. We wrote that your receivers 'peaked when Fortnite did' and that you needed to 'sell a vet and pivot before the window slams shut.' Instead, Derrick Henry went for 28.7 points and Jalen Hurts added 24.28, and suddenly the aging stars look less like a hospice ward and more like the 2004 Pistons — a team nobody believed in that just keeps winning anyway. Your 151.48 points led the league. Jalen Hurts is a cheat code, your three-headed RB monster of Henry, Jacobs, and Kyren Williams combined for 55.6 points, and the group chat is doing that thing where they pretend they saw this coming. They didn't. Nobody did. Enjoy it — because the schedule gets real next week when you face General Ken-obi.

Josh Allen scored 38.76 points in Week 1. That's not a stat, that's a hate crime against your opponent's scoreboard. ToreroGaucho has been waiting for a performance like this since we wrote in the preseason that 'your WR room is a meme waiting to happen.' Turns out, you don't need receivers when your quarterback IS the offense. De'Von Achane chipped in 16.0 and Bucky Irving added 12.5 — the rookie RB committee doing exactly what we hoped. You beat Noble FFT by 11.14 points, and if Allen plays anywhere near this level consistently, the 'stuck in fifth' narrative dies. The question remains: what happens when Allen has a 15-point week and your receivers have to carry the load? We both know the answer.

The defending champion opened with a 143.72-point win over Chudders and nobody blinked. That's the Kittler brand — you show up, you score, you win, and the group chat talks about someone else. Garrett Wilson (19.0) and Puka Nacua (18.1) combined for 37.1 at receiver, which is exactly the kind of quiet dominance that carried you to the 2024 title. We said your ceiling was 'drywall' in the preseason. Drywall that wins games is still drywall that wins games. Runner-up in 2022, runner-up in 2023, champion in 2024, and now a solid Week 1. The pattern holds. You face Noble FFT next — a team that just lost and will be desperate. That's when consistency matters most.

We ranked you dead last in the preseason. Twelfth. The bottom. We said Lamar, Tyreek, and Kelce were 'approaching age cliffs' and that 'your lack of picks makes retooling tricky.' Then Lamar went out and scored 29.36 points, James Cook added 18.7, Jaxon Smith-Njigba contributed 13.9, and you obliterated Ghastly Grayskull Gang by 34.94 points — the week's biggest blowout. In the group chat you're 'often the instigator of side bets and polls,' so we imagine you've already started a poll asking whether the preseason rankings should be burned. Fair point. One week doesn't make a season, but 144.36 points is a statement. Maybe those age cliffs have guardrails after all.

You won. That's the good news. The bad news is that you scored 135.88 points — a perfectly respectable total that somehow feels underwhelming when you're the preseason number-one team with 'a WR corps that could headline Coachella.' Saquon Barkley delivered 16.4 and CeeDee Lamb added 14.5, but Drake Maye at quarterback only managed 15.28, and the roster that 'reads like the All-Pro team' looked more like the All-Adequate team. You beat Father Time by 15.2 points, which is comfortable, but the ceiling we talked about in the preseason — the 'limitless' ceiling — stayed firmly above you. Next week you get Sleeping Giants and their 151-point Week 1. Time to wake up.

Patrick Mahomes went for 26.02, Christian McCaffrey had 19.2, and you quietly pocketed a win over Burden of Etienne-y Woody. Nobody's writing ballads about 131.72 points, but after we said in the preseason that 'a rebuild may be closer than you think,' a Week 1 win feels like a reprieve. The 2022 champion is still alive, the Voltron receivers didn't need to assemble, and Mahomes did Mahomes things. Your tight-end room is still a ghost town — Hunter Henry exists in the way a participation trophy exists — but hey, you're 1-0. Next week you face a Ghastly team that just got embarrassed. Should be a good spot.

You scored 142.62 points and lost. In most leagues, in most weeks, 142.62 wins. But you drew Sleeping Giants and their 151.48-point eruption, and suddenly the preseason number-three team is sitting at 0-1 wondering what went wrong. Nothing went wrong, actually — Jayden Daniels scored 20.12, Myles Garrett had 22.0 on defense, and even the patchwork running backs showed up (Chuba Hubbard: 16.4). You were the second-highest-scoring losing team in Week 1, which is dynasty football's version of 'the food was great but the restaurant burned down.' We said you were 'a trade or rookie breakout away from a title.' That's still true. The loss stings, but 142 points means the engine works.

Justin Herbert threw for 27.92 points and Emeka Egbuka had 21.6, which is more production than we expected from a team we projected at 38.6 points per week. You actually scored 133.82, which is thirty-five points above your preseason projection. The problem? You drew the defending champion, and Kittler doesn't lose games you're supposed to win. Ashton Jeanty only managed 11.0, and the 'best young RB duo in the league' looked more like one good RB and one guy figuring out the NFL. We said you were 'playing for 2026.' That might still be true. But 133 points in a loss suggests the rebuild is ahead of schedule.

Preseason number two. Week 1 number nine. Bijan Robinson delivered 21.4 and Breece Hall had 15.5 — the 'scariest backfield in the league' did its job. But Caleb Williams was nowhere to be found in your starting lineup, you started Jordan Love (15.92), and Josh Allen dropped 38.76 on the other side. That's the Josh Allen problem: you can do everything right and still lose because one quarterback decided to play like a video game. We wrote that you needed 'an elite tight end and a little receiver depth.' After Week 1, add 'divine intervention against Josh Allen' to that list. You face Kittler next. Opportunity to prove the preseason ranking wasn't fiction.

120.68 points and a loss to General Ken-obi. Brock Purdy started at quarterback (18.78) instead of Bo Nix, which is either a savvy play or a sign that your QB room is a weekly guessing game. Ladd McConkey only mustered 10.4, and those 'wagyu beef receivers' looked more like grocery-store sushi. We said you were 'a classic spoiler who knocks contenders out of the playoffs but never raises the trophy.' Week 1 didn't do anything to change that narrative. You face MHJTIME next — a team that just scored 142 in a loss and is looking for someone to take it out on. Good luck.

Justin Jefferson scored 12.8 points. Twelve-point-eight. From a top-three dynasty asset. Meanwhile, Kyler Murray managed 18.32, James Conner added 12.4, and your highest scorer was... the Denver Broncos defense at 18.0 points. When your defense outscores your franchise receiver, something has gone structurally wrong. We called you 'a cautionary tale of stars without support' in the preseason. Week 1 was the cautionary tale writing itself in real time. Your 120.32 points fell to the Legion of Bouz by 11.4. The group chat rumours about trading Jefferson for a king's ransom? They might be getting louder after this.

109.42 points. The week's lowest score by twenty points. C.J. Stroud managed 9.72 — the kind of performance that makes you check if your lineup was actually set. Brock Bowers had 13.8, which is fine for a tight end, but when your tight end is your second-highest scorer behind Deebo Samuel's 19.1, the 'picks don't score points' crowd in the group chat is going to have a field day. You were the preseason number-four team. You were supposed to prove that the rebuild was working. Instead, The Boonist Monks beat you by 34.94 points. That mountain of draft picks? Still a mountain. Still not scoring points. We'll check back in Week 2 when you face the Legion of Bouz.

confessionals.text: They said we were done. They said sell the vets. They said Derrick Henry had too many carries and our receivers peaked when Fortnite did. Then Derrick went for 28.7, Hurts dropped 24.28, and we put up 151. I texted the group chat one word: 'Awake.' Nobody responded for eleven minutes. Those were the best eleven minutes of my fantasy career.

I scored 142.62 points. One hundred and forty-two. I would have beaten ten of the twelve teams in this league this week. I drew the one team whose running backs apparently discovered the fountain of youth. Jayden Daniels played great. Myles Garrett played great. I still lost. If you need me, I'll be staring at the schedule trying to figure out when the fantasy gods plan to apologize.

C.J. Stroud scored 9.72 points. Nine. Seven. Two. I have more draft picks than points from my starting quarterback. The Boonist Monks beat me by thirty-five. I didn't open the group chat for the rest of Sunday. Or Monday. I might open it Tuesday. Probably not.

Bijan had 21.4. Breece had 15.5. The backfield did everything we asked. Then Josh Allen decided to score 38.76 points on the other side, which is a thing that apparently can just happen to you in this league. Nobody warned me. Nobody could have. This is fine.

mailbag.question: Dear Commish: We spent the entire offseason being told that Sleeping Giants needed to blow it up and rebuild. What happened?
mailbag.answer: Derrick Henry happened. 28.7 points from a man with more career carries than some cars have miles. Also Jalen Hurts happened. Also Josh Jacobs happened. Sometimes the universe looks at your preseason rankings, laughs, and hands the eleventh-ranked team 151 points just to remind you that projections are suggestions, not prophecies.

mailbag.question: @rango_ asks: How do you score 142 points and still lose? Seriously. How?
mailbag.answer: By playing against a team that scores 151. That's the cruel math of fantasy football — there's no moral victory for second-highest score of the week. You lose 0-1 the same way someone who scored 90 loses 0-1. The universe doesn't grade on a curve. But if it makes you feel better, your 142.62 would have won against every other team in the league this week. That probably doesn't make you feel better.

mailbag.question: From the group chat: Should we be concerned that the preseason top-three teams went 1-2 in Week 1?
mailbag.answer: Concerned? No. Amused? Absolutely. General Ken-obi won but didn't look dominant. Noble FFT ran into the Josh Allen buzzsaw. MHJTIME outscored most of the league and still lost. It's one week. Ask me again in Week 6 when we have actual sample sizes. But for now, it's a useful reminder that preseason rankings are built on projections and vibes, and vibes don't block for your running back.

mailbag.question: @GrayskullXX asks: Is it too early to panic about C.J. Stroud?
mailbag.answer: It's too early to panic about anything. It's Week 1. Stroud had 9.72 points, which is bad, but Tom Brady once threw for 123 yards in a game and then won six Super Bowls. Bad weeks happen. However — and I say this with love — your team scored 109.42 points total. That's not a Stroud problem. That's an everything problem. Those draft picks need to start converting into actual fantasy-relevant football players, or we're having this same conversation in Week 14.

mailbag.question: Dear Expert: The Boonist Monks were ranked last in the preseason and just put up 144. Should we burn the preseason rankings?
mailbag.answer: No, but you should laminate them for reference. Lamar Jackson went for 29.36, James Cook had 18.7, and the 'aging core approaching age cliffs' looked like they were approaching the summit instead. One week doesn't invalidate a preseason projection, but it does make excellent group chat ammunition. GauchoTrain has probably already screenshotted the preseason essay and is drafting his response.

bits.title: Great Call of the Week
bits.text: Starting Derrick Henry in the Year of Our Lord 2025 and watching him drop 28.7 points like it's 2020. zbcowan didn't overthink it. He started his guys. His guys delivered. Sometimes the best strategy is no strategy at all.

bits.title: Parent Corner
bits.text: Trying to explain to your spouse why you're upset about scoring 142.62 points. 'But you scored a lot?' 'Yes.' 'And you still lost?' 'Yes.' 'So the points don't matter?' 'They matter, they just don't matter enough.' This conversation has never ended well for anyone.

bits.title: Nobody Believes in Us
bits.text: The Boonist Monks, ranked twelfth in the preseason, dropping 144.36 points and the week's biggest blowout (34.94 margin). GauchoTrain has been collecting receipts all offseason. Week 1 was the first deposit.

bits.title: Overheard in the Chat
bits.text: 'Stroud had 9.72 points' — posted without context by three different people within six minutes of each other. GrayskullXX's response: a single period. The most devastating punctuation in group chat history.

bits.title: Things I Believe But Can't Prove
bits.text: Sleeping Giants will not finish first. The Boonist Monks will not finish fourth. MHJTIME will finish higher than seventh. And Josh Allen will have at least two more weeks above 35 points, because he's Josh Allen and the rest of us just live in his league.

picks.blurb: The preseason number-one versus the Week 1 number-one. General Ken-obi has the deeper roster, but Sleeping Giants just put up 151 and have the momentum of a team that proved every doubter wrong. Hurts and Henry are rolling, and until someone slows them down, we're riding the hot hand. Upset watch? Maybe. But 151 points earns you the benefit of the doubt.

The defending champion versus a team that just got Josh Allen'd. Noble FFT has the backfield to compete, but Kittler's consistency is suffocating. Wilson, Nacua, Burrow — they don't have 38-point ceilings, but they don't have 9-point floors either. Give us the steady hand after a loss week.
Mahomes and McCaffrey versus a team that scored 109.42 in Week 1. Ghastly needs a bounceback, but drawing the 2022 champ on the road isn't the spot for it. Legion should control this one comfortably.

Josh Allen might not repeat 38.76, but even a 'normal' Allen week plus Achane and Irving should be enough against a rebuilding Chudders squad. Herbert and Jeanty can keep it interesting, but the talent gap is wide. Rasheeing cruises.

MHJTIME scored 142 and lost. Father Time scored 120 and also lost. One of these teams has Ja'Marr Chase, Malik Nabers, Marvin Harrison Jr., and Trey McBride. The other has Bo Nix and ramen noodle running backs. This should be cathartic for rango_.

Lamar just dropped 29.36 and Cook had 18.7. Burden's best player was the Denver Broncos defense. Justin Jefferson scoring 12.8 is not the kind of production that beats a team coming off a 34-point blowout win. The Monks keep it rolling.

special_picks.stay_away: Kittler on the Roof vs Noble FFT
special_picks.teaser: Parlay MHJTIME -5 with The Legion of Bouz -3.5
